Title: Stylistic inversion
References: ŠTULAJTEROVÁ, A., JESENSKÁ, P.: English Stylistics. 1. vyd. Banská Bystrica : Univerzita Mateja Bela, 2013. 114 s.
Content:
Stylistic inversion (also known as anastrophe) is a literary technique in which the normal order of words is reversed in order to achieve a particular effect or emphasis.

Such reversal of the major sentence elements word order concerns mainly the subject and verb. For example, inversion of the subject and verb is extremely common in poetry.

  • "Ten thousand saw I in the mist.." - Wordsworth

examples:

  • What a beautiful picture it is!
  • Had I known he was drunk.
